segments.Text: That there was child porn on IRC.
Please.
Again, when I was informed that there was child pornography on the internet on the internet,
I was extremely offended and we started an organization that was extremely militant.
We started out as the ACPM, the anti-child porn militia.
Within the first three weeks of our organization, we got 300 volunteers.
A hundred of those volunteers signed up as hackers.
We thought that there was a solution, if there's child porn a server, let the boys go out there,
the server, remove the information. If there was child porn on an ISP, notify them, have them
to remove that information. As you all know, that information is backed up on CD's other hard drives.
That does absolutely no good. When we came here last year to DEFCOM, we were looking for hackers.
While we were here, one of our board people, one of the people in our organization,
said something that I've really paid attention to. You cannot stop a felony with a felony.
Our main goal is to put these people in prison.
That is the only way they're going to stop dispensing child pornography and wounding children and killing children.
In order to do that, we had to embrace law enforcement.
We now work directly with law enforcement, other organizations such as missing children, FBI, U.S. Customs, UNESCO.
UNESCO. One of the things that we've done with our hacking community is we've redirected their energy.
And they now are building tools to help us fight child pornography.
We have one tool in particular that goes out and spiders out child porn on the internet.
We are refining that tool according to law enforcement's requirements to do a better job.
If we send in all the reports we get of child pornography, they cannot
deal with it. It's overwhelming. But if we refine those reports and do part of their job,
to make their job easier, we have better equipment, we have more time, we have more bandwidth,
then they can do their job better.
We are now a non-for-profit organization. We have a structure. We have a board of directors.
If you go to our website, look at their bios.
We have businessmen. We have actually two parts to ACPO. We have ACPO. We have ACPO.
We have ACPO.
and we have Team ACPO. Team ACPO is made up of our programmers and our developers.
ACPO, board of directors, myself, go through background checks.
Anybody dealing directly that close with our organization goes to background checks.
Our coders do not.
A few of them do because they're working on specific tools, so we have to check who we're dealing with.
Well, at this point, I think what I'm going to do, we also have a huge liaison program.
program all over the United States, all over the world.
One of the goals of the liaisons is to look for law enforcement contacts.
This is DeQuest.
He's our French liaison and our European representative.
Hi.
Hi, everyone. As she told you, I'm coming from France.
I'll take care of the European part of the European part.
European part of ACPO because this child porn thing is not only a disaster in America,
but also over Europe, where we do have like a lot of child porn, not only website, but a really
well-organized system.
One of my job with ACPO is to take care not only to get contacts, like for example, we get
we get really good contacts at the UNESCO, because we are an official, as Natchez-sa previously,
with a non-profit status now. It's like a real organization, not only a website,
and we're trying to build a big network of contacts in official agency all over Europe,
because it's really important to take care of this part of the, of the, of the country.
of the continent.
The other thing is about the team ACPA was in Natchase previously.
We do have many programmers who join us directly by our website
because we're trying to build a lot of tools
in different language, running different platforms,
we can use to automatize the maximum of the tasks
because we went like when we started two years ago,
ago, from single copy and paste, from a submission from the website, to now fitting directly
databases with all the information, all those reports we get from website, from emails, and
it saved a lot of time. It will help us to be more efficient on the result and all the information
we will grab from those reports.
The other part, for the information we will grab from those reports.
The other part, for the data.
Our team ACPO is to build some kind of donationware, is to make some software running
on different operating system that family will be able to use at home just to make sure the
kids are surfing and don't see this kind of pictures or those kind of website.
So that's one of the biggest plan we got at this time is to release 100% cross-platform software.
to filter not only with keywords, but with all the technical parts to prevent this from happening to kids.
So we're working on this and that's why we need some programmers for this team ACPO.
No matter of the skills you have, it depends, because we will not focus on any language at this time to build this kind of software.
or any people with C++ with any language would be really helpful to us.
For the website part, for making the software, for creating those databases,
and I think there's a lot of job to do on this part.
The other point is about our needs. Of course, we need some not only software, not hard
but we need bandwidth.
At this time, all our information are gathered on computers around the world.
One of the main aim is to get local and small and pretty secure network operations center
with dedicated line database system, like regular network operations center, sorry.
So as a non-profit organization, at this time we're able to receive donations from companies,
companies from any people and it already helps us a lot this, I don't know what's
a word, it's in America, it's the 501 , that's the technical word for the nonprofit.
There's a lot of, a lot of things to do with ACPO if you have programming skills,
if you have skilled at all. We don't ask for anyone to work like 20,000 people.
24 hours a day, if they just want to spare some time with us, if they feel like doing it,
everyone is welcome, really.
Thank you, Diki.
And we also, as one of our board of directors likes to put it, we're kind of an umbrella that has met with other organizations
doing basically the same thing we're doing trying to stop child porn on the internet.
We have a sister organization in Germany, anti-kinder porno,
who met with us at Myrtle Beach and law enforcement. They've been around for about six years.
We have a group in Denmark that we're closely associated with. And at this time, I'd like to introduce
you to a locksley from... You never get it right. I don't, I get locks from condemn.org.
I'm R. Locksley. This is Blueberry. This is our Australian component. Some of you may know me
as kind of the hacker contingent. And we started exactly like
they did. We didn't call ourselves a militia, although if I had thought of it, we probably
would have. We figured that, and it was really Blue and Vort, the other people from Australia,
that started this, they brought up a website, and they knew that I was out there doing it
anyway. And they said, hey, you, you're old, you got a big mouth, you want to come and help.
So we kind of got in bed together right away. And we started in the same way. We started going
and right on the website it says we take child pornographers off the net in any way we can.
What's the exact wording?
That's about it.
Any way we can. Well, I got hooked up. Some of you know the name most hated, unfortunately now in jail.
But one of the good things that he did was introduce me to Natasha and her crew.
And she said to us, well, you guys are going through what we went through about, you know, what was it a year and a half?
two years ago. And after many screaming phone calls in the middle of the night and,
you know, her sitting me down and in the channel and saying, you know, you need to listen,
I finally came to the realization that as much as I hate to admit it, she's right.
And our group now is 100% legitimate. However, we do have a lot of people that come to us and say,
listen, we found these sites. What do you want us to do?
and we tell them we want you to report them on the site and we will take care of them.
Now unfortunately, and I'm hoping my law enforcement contact next to me doesn't shoot me,
but unfortunately they don't have as much bandwidth as we do.
They don't have as much time.
So what we find is that they'll go and they'll look at the site three or four times, these hackers,
and if it's not gone, a lot of the time they take it down themselves.
Now, I will not go out and let me step back.
Let me step back. When they come to me, I'll always advise them about the law, as I understand
it, and I just kind of got my head handed to me. I didn't understand one piece of it.
I've always felt that it was morally right to do this, morally right to go and, you know,
yeah, it is a felony to perpetrate a felony, but something that I was missing was that when we go out there
and we hack these sites, a lot of the time we're stealing evidence from people like them
who were in a legitimate investigation trying to put these people in jail.
And this is what Natasha has been screaming at me about for about the last six months.
So I will not go out and tell a hacker not to hack a pedophile site.
But I will tell them what the legalities are, why you shouldn't do it,
and explain to them what the consequences are, potential consequences,
which I just got schooled on this morning, was kind of pretty embarrassing.
But if it's a little bit of,
But if it's a choice between hacking NASA and a pedophile site, I think everybody knows what recommendation I'm going to give them.
For us, it's been a hard transition because the people that I deal with are hackers.
They are people that want to go out, they want to hack things,
and they want it to be something that morally right, they can kind of jump on the bandwagon,
and do something that they can perform an active conscience, which they still do.
Now, I'm trying to change that.
I'm not recruiting.
don't need any bandwidth, don't need web space, don't need anything.
We have all of that.
All I'm saying is that get involved.
You know, whether, you know, we don't, yeah, sure, everybody needs money,
but we're not looking for that either.
If you know a congressman, senator, anything like that, write them a letter
and say to them, listen, these guys are right.
They need to, the congressmen and senators need to start changing some of the laws
to give them teeth.
One of the things that Natasha, I'm really supposed,
with your mouth that you didn't bring this up.
There is a particular law that we have been looking at
and we're now actively in the process of trying to change.
If somebody goes out and rapes a child,
they can get 10 to 20 years.
If that person is related to that child,
generally they get probation.
We find that unacceptable.
You know, by definition a child trusts that family member,
and we find it very difficult to set that type of a precedent to a child.
And nobody knows that. That's the thing. So that's one example, please.
Just get on the phone. If you know senators, congressmen, just in your home states.
Just write them a letter and say, go look at condemn.org and see if you can help us.
That's all. That's all I ask.
And did you want to say anything?
This is Blueberry. Hopefully you can understand her accent.
Hi. I just want, I've had a thought that I really think the industry should start regulating itself.
I'm talking about the people who run web hosting services.
web hosting services.
Yeah.
I think that unless people who start filtering their own content,
look at what they're putting online before they just put it up.
Otherwise, we're looking at censorship down the line.
You're giving government's reasons to install software that prohibits people viewing things.
We're not for censorship.
With the industry starting to look at what they're putting online,
if they stop putting it out there, we don't have to take it down anymore.
I mean, sure they're going to move to somewhere else.
Perhaps an easier place for us to catch them online, like IRC, you know?
like IRC, you know? So if any of you guys are web hosting, check your content first, please, please.
Boy, I didn't think you're going to say anything.
On that note, back to you, Nat. Thank you for listening.
And I'd like to introduce you to Detective Mark Laderman, and he'll tell you more about himself.
My name is Mark Lanerman. I'm a detective from Minneapolis
and I'm currently assigned to the Minnesota High Tech Crime Task Force.
Yeah, I can't believe no one spotted me.
He's my fad.
Anyway, I can certainly appreciate the frustration
that several attendees of this convention have
regarding hacking child porn websites.
However, I do have to caution you that
if I am investigating a crime,
if I am investigating an authorized computer access in the state,
to Minnesota, it is punishable by a five-year felony.
And that's to start with. I don't have to show intent.
I don't have to show damage. I have to show access.
That's very easy for me to do. So I just want to caution you about doing that.
I certainly appreciate the morals behind doing this. I certainly appreciate why someone
would want to go ahead and do this. And if I wasn't in law enforcement, I don't know what I would be doing about it.
I just don't want to see someone with good intentions get more trouble than what they realized could have happened to them.
Also, I do want to keep this brief.
So I just want to touch on one other topic.
There's this misperception that if someone wants to report child pornography on the web, on the Internet,
that they want to go to the feds right away.
Well, believe it or not, your local and state authorities have more
much more authority in dealing with these crimes than the feds do.
And I tell you that firsthand, as quite often federal agencies come to me asking for assistance
in Minnesota.
So, you know, I don't want to tell you folks, don't go to the feds if you want to report something,
but certainly try your local and state authorities first also.
Thank you.
But if you do find it, report it, please.
At this point, we are going to open the questions.
and answers.
Yes, ma'am?
We wanted to keep this real brief because we know it's sandwich.
Yes.
Well, that's one of the things that we're doing with Team ACP.
She wants to know how we're going to know where the website is.
That's one of the things that Team ACP has done is written a script now.
So all our reports run through a process.

information we can. The next step of that, and that goes off to
nitmick, a missing children, customs, and the feds.

then if you're the Alabama liaison, you will have given us law enforcement connections
in Alabama. It will be sent to them also.

And we'll never have enough, because it's such a global problem.
Nat, you can get me if I talk to me.
Go ahead.

It's everywhere.

it's too long.

back up. So you can really please try to love you,

Something else I wanted to say, too.
We were sent some information to
sent over to law enforcement. We were sent 11.5 megs of text off of a child porn

we don't have to forget that the main aim is exactly the same, is to prevent to take the child porn from, to take out the child porn from the internet.

because it's two different organizations that we won't speak to each other. That's why today we are at the same table,
is to make sure we don't make them waste some time on the site or if they don't do it,

behind this. It's a well-organized network of child porn. Some people say previously,
